title: Sentence Types — Declarative and Interrogative
description: Students learn to identify and write declarative sentences (statements) and interrogative sentences (questions). They examine punctuation differences and practice converting between the two types.
instructions:
1. Write a declarative sentence on the board: 'The Great Wall of China is very long.'
2. Ask what kind of sentence it is — it tells us something, it's a statement.
3. Write an interrogative sentence: 'How long is the Great Wall of China?'
4. Discuss: this one asks something. It's a question.
5. Point out the punctuation difference (period vs. question mark).
6. Practice: give students 5 declarative sentences to convert into questions, and 5 questions to convert into statements.
7. Students write 3 original declarative and 3 original interrogative sentences in their journals.

slides.heading: Types of Sentences
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is like the title page of a book, telling us what we're going to learn about: different kinds of sentences! We're going to become super sentence detectives and figure out two special types: ones that tell us things and ones that ask things.

slides.setup_instructions: Have two example sentences pre-written on the board, covered until ready to reveal.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, look at this list! We need a whiteboard and some markers so we can write our sentences, just like a teacher would. We also need your grammar journal and a pencil to write down your own amazing sentences later. The sentence type chart is like a cheat sheet that will help us remember everything we learn.

slides.text: Reveal the first sentence: 'The Great Wall of China is very long.' Ask: 'What does this sentence do? It tells us a fact. We call this a declarative sentence — it declares something. It ends with a period.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Alright, let's look at this first sentence! It tells us something, right? It's like a fact. Sentences that tell us facts or statements are called "declarative" sentences, and they always finish with a little dot called a period.

slides.text: Reveal the second sentence: 'How long is the Great Wall of China?' Ask: 'What does this one do? It asks a question! We call this an interrogative sentence. Interrogate means to ask questions. It ends with a question mark.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, check out this next sentence! See how it's asking us something? It wants to know information. Sentences that ask questions are called "interrogative" sentences, and they always end with a special squiggle called a question mark.

slides.text: Practice converting together: 'Pandas eat bamboo.' becomes 'Do pandas eat bamboo?' Show how the word order changes and the punctuation switches. Do three more together.
slides.mascot_explanation: Here's where we get to practice being sentence wizards! We're going to take a sentence that tells us something and flip it into a question, and then take a question and turn it back into a statement. We'll change how the words are ordered and switch the punctuation from a period to a question mark, or the other way around!

slides.prompt: Convert 5 declarative sentences into interrogative sentences and 5 interrogative sentences into declarative sentences. Then write 3 original sentences of each type in your journal.
slides.mascot_explanation: This is the big activity! You get to be the writer. You'll change some sentences from telling to asking, and some from asking to telling. Then, you'll even get to make up your very own sentences of both types to show off what you know. You've got this!

slides.text: Review: A declarative sentence makes a statement and ends with a period. An interrogative sentence asks a question and ends with a question mark. Tomorrow we will learn two more sentence types!
slides.mastery_check: Can the student identify and write both declarative and interrogative sentences with correct punctuation?
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, you did it! We learned that sentences that tell us things are declarative and end with a period, and sentences that ask questions are interrogative and end with a question mark. You're becoming such a great sentence expert, and tomorrow we'll learn even more!

parent_notes: This lesson introduces two of the four sentence types. In Montessori grammar, sentence analysis is a key part of understanding how language works. Encourage your child to find examples of each type in their reading throughout the week. Notice how news articles use mostly declarative sentences while interviews use interrogative ones.

title: Decimals — Introduction to Hundredths
description: Building on their understanding of tenths, students extend decimal place value to hundredths. They use the decimal board and hundred squares to visualize how one whole is divided into 100 equal parts.
instructions:
1. Review tenths: show the decimal board with 10 strips making one whole.
2. Take one tenth strip and divide it into 10 equal parts — each part is one hundredth.
3. Write 0.01 on the board. 'This is one hundredth. It takes 100 of these to make one whole.'
4. Show the hundred square grid: shade 1 square = 0.01, shade 10 squares = 0.10 = one tenth.
5. Practice reading decimals: 0.25 = 2 tenths and 5 hundredths = 25 hundredths.
6. Students shade hundred grids to represent various decimals: 0.15, 0.42, 0.73, 0.08, 0.90.
7. Write each decimal in expanded form (e.g., 0.42 = 4 tenths + 2 hundredths).
materials_needed: Hundred square grids (printed, at least 10 per student)
Place value chart extended to hundredths

slides.heading: Decimals
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is like the title page of our adventure! It tells us we're going to learn all about "Decimals" and a special new kind called "Hundredths." It's like unlocking a secret level in a game!

slides.setup_instructions: Print multiple hundred square grids. Have the decimal board set up with the tenths strips from previous lessons.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, let's get our tools ready for this math adventure! We've got a "Decimal board" which helps us see how numbers are put together, "Hundred square grids" that look like graph paper with 100 little boxes, "Colored pencils" to do some shading, a "Place value chart" to help us organize our numbers, and a "Whiteboard" for writing things down. You'll need to gather these with a grown-up.

slides.text: Review: 'Remember our tenths? One whole divided into 10 equal parts. Each part is one tenth, written 0.1.' Show on the decimal board. 'But what if we divide each tenth into 10 MORE parts?'
slides.mascot_explanation: This part is a quick reminder of what we learned before. See the big rectangle on the board? Imagine it's a whole candy bar, and we've already cut it into 10 equal pieces, called tenths (0.1). Now, we're going to take that even further and see what happens when we cut *each* of those pieces into 10 smaller pieces!

slides.text: Hold up the hundred square grid. 'This whole square is ONE. It has 100 tiny squares inside. Each tiny square is one hundredth: 0.01.' Count out a row: 'Ten hundredths make one tenth: 0.10 equals 0.1.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at this square! It's like a tiny tile made up of 100 super small squares. Each one of those super small squares is called a "hundredth," and we write it as 0.01. If we count out 10 of these tiny squares in a row, it makes one of the bigger pieces we talked about before – a tenth (0.10, which is the same as 0.1)! Isn't it neat how they connect?

slides.text: Write 0.25 on the board. Shade 25 squares on the grid. 'This is 2 tenths and 5 hundredths — or 25 hundredths. Both ways of reading it are correct.' Practice with 0.50, 0.73, and 0.08.
slides.mascot_explanation: Here we see the number 0.25. Think of the hundred square grid – this means we've shaded in 25 of those tiny squares. We can say this as "2 tenths and 5 hundredths" because 25 squares is two full rows of 10 (that's 2 tenths) plus 5 more squares. Or, we can just say it's "25 hundredths" because it's 25 of the tiniest squares! Both ways are right!

slides.prompt: Shade hundred grids to show each decimal: 0.15, 0.42, 0.73, 0.08, 0.90. Then write each in expanded form (tenths + hundredths). Challenge: what decimal does 100 shaded squares represent?
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's your turn to be the artist and the mathematician! You'll use your colored pencils to shade in the hundred square grids to match the numbers on the screen, like 0.15 or 0.42. After you shade them, write down what that number means using "tenths" and "hundredths," like 0.42 is 4 tenths and 2 hundredths. You've got this!

slides.text: One hundredth is written 0.01. The hundredths place is two places to the right of the decimal point. Ten hundredths equal one tenth, and one hundred hundredths equal one whole.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student read, write, and represent decimals to the hundredths place using hundred square grids?
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, you did it! You learned that 0.01 is one tiny square, and the hundredths place is the second spot after the decimal point. You saw how 10 hundredths make a tenth, and 100 hundredths make a whole thing! You're a decimal whiz, showing you can read, write, and shade numbers all the way to the hundredths place!

parent_notes: Hundredths connect beautifully to money (pennies and dollars) and percentages. The hundred square grid is a powerful visual — 25 shaded squares clearly shows 0.25, which is also 25 cents or 25%. Let your child practice with real coins: 1 penny = $0.01 = one hundredth of a dollar.

title: Ancient China — The Great Wall
description: Students learn about the Great Wall of China — why it was built, how it was constructed over centuries by different dynasties, and what it reveals about ancient Chinese civilization. They locate it on the timeline and map.
instructions:
1. Place Ancient China on the timeline — it overlaps with Egypt and Mesopotamia.
2. Show China on the map. Point out its vast size and natural borders (Himalayas, Pacific Ocean).
3. Ask: 'What would you do if enemies kept attacking from the north?' Discuss defensive strategies.
4. Introduce the Great Wall: started by Qin Shi Huang around 221 BCE, but built over many dynasties.
5. Discuss construction: millions of workers, rammed earth and stone, watchtowers every few hundred meters.
6. Show images of the Wall winding across mountains.
7. Students draw a cross-section of the Wall showing its layers and a watchtower.
8. Add Ancient China to the class timeline.

slides.heading: Ancient China
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide is introducing us to our new topic: Ancient China and its super famous Great Wall! Get ready to learn about a giant wall that snakes across a whole country.

slides.setup_instructions: Have the timeline visible with Egypt and Mesopotamia already marked. Print high-quality photos of the Great Wall from different angles.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, we need to gather our supplies for our adventure today. We'll need the timeline we've been using, a map or globe to find China, some cool pictures of the Great Wall, paper and crayons for drawing, and a book if we want to learn extra facts.

slides.text: 'We have traveled through Mesopotamia, Egypt, and India. Today we journey east to CHINA!' Show China on the map. 'Look how enormous it is. Ancient Chinese civilization began along two great rivers — the Yellow River and the Yangtze River — around the same time as Egypt.'
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide shows us where China is on the map. Wow, it's HUGE! Just like some of the other places we've learned about, like Egypt, a really old and important civilization started here a long, long time ago, right by some big rivers.

slides.text: 'China had a big problem: nomadic warriors from the north kept raiding villages and stealing food. What would YOU do to protect your people?' Let the child brainstorm. 'Emperor Qin Shi Huang had a bold idea — build a wall across the ENTIRE northern border!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Imagine if someone was always trying to sneak into your backyard and take your toys – you'd want to build a fence, right? The ancient Chinese had a similar problem with people from the north trying to attack them, so their leader decided to build a giant wall to keep everyone safe.

slides.text: 'The Great Wall was not built all at once. Different dynasties added to it over about 2,000 years! Workers packed earth between wooden frames, then later used stone and brick. Watchtowers were built so guards could see enemies approaching and light signal fires to warn the next tower.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Building the Great Wall was a HUGE job that took many, many years, and lots of different groups of people helped build it. They used dirt packed super tight and then later, bricks and stones, and they built tall towers so guards could watch out for trouble.

slides.prompt: Draw a cross-section of the Great Wall showing: the stone/brick outer walls, the packed earth fill, a walkway on top wide enough for horses, and a watchtower. Label each part. On the back, write three facts you learned.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's your turn to be an architect and draw your own Great Wall! You need to draw the outside walls, the dirt inside, a path on top, and a watchtower, and then label them all. On the back, write down three cool things you learned about the wall.

slides.text: The Great Wall stretches over 13,000 miles — longer than the distance from New York to Los Angeles and back! It took millions of workers and nearly 2,000 years. It is one of the greatest building achievements in human history.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student explain why the Great Wall was built, describe its basic construction, and locate China on a map?
slides.mascot_explanation: You did it! We learned that the Great Wall is incredibly long, took almost 2,000 years to build with millions of workers, and was a super smart way for ancient China to protect itself. Isn't it amazing what people can build?

parent_notes: Ancient China is a rich topic that will span several weeks. The Great Wall provides a dramatic entry point. If possible, watch a short documentary clip about the Wall. Discuss the human cost — many workers died during construction. This is an opportunity to talk about the ethics of massive building projects. Compare to the pyramids of Egypt.

title: China — Physical Features and Great Rivers
description: Students explore the physical geography of China: the Yellow River (Huang He), Yangtze River, Himalayan mountains, Gobi Desert, and eastern plains. They understand how geography shaped Chinese civilization.
instructions:
1. Show a physical map of China with elevation coloring.
2. Identify major features: Himalayas (south/southwest), Gobi Desert (north), Tibetan Plateau, eastern plains.
3. Trace the Yellow River (Huang He): 'Called the cradle of Chinese civilization.' Discuss the yellow silt.
4. Trace the Yangtze River: longest in Asia, flows through fertile farmland.
5. Discuss how geography isolated China: mountains, desert, and ocean on three sides.
6. Students create a labeled physical map of China showing: both rivers, Himalayas, Gobi Desert, Tibetan Plateau, Pacific Ocean, Great Wall location.
7. Color-code by elevation.
materials_needed: Colored pencils (blue, brown, green, yellow, tan)

slides.heading: Geography of China
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is like the title page of our adventure! It tells us we're going to learn all about the amazing lands and giant rivers of China. We'll discover mountains, deserts, and waterways that helped shape this incredible country.

slides.setup_instructions: Print a blank outline map of China. Have the physical elevation map displayed for reference.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, time to gather our explorer tools! First, you'll need that big map of China that shows all the different colors for how high or low the land is. Then, grab your blank map of China and your colored pencils so we can make our own map! We'll also use the atlas or globe if we need to check where things are.

slides.text: 'Let us look at China from above! See these colors on the map? Brown and white mean very high mountains. Green means low, flat plains. Yellow-tan means desert.' Point out the dramatic elevation changes from west to east.
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at this map! See all the different colors? The browns and whites mean super tall mountains, like giants reaching for the sky. The greens show us flat, low lands where lots of people might live, and the yellowy-tan color tells us where the dry, sandy deserts are. It's like looking at China's different heights!

slides.text: 'Here are the Himalayas — the tallest mountains on Earth — blocking the southwest. Here is the Gobi Desert in the north, one of the largest deserts in the world. And here is the Pacific Ocean to the east. China was naturally protected on almost every side!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at those huge mountains called the Himalayas in the southwest – they're the tallest on Earth! And way up north is the giant Gobi Desert, so big and dry. To the east, there's the huge Pacific Ocean. These things acted like a giant shield, keeping China safe and a bit separate from other places.

slides.text: 'Now the rivers: the Yellow River carries golden-yellow silt, which is why it is named Huang He — Yellow River. Farmers grew crops in this rich soil. The Yangtze is even longer — the third longest river in the world! It flows through the heart of China.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now let's talk about the super important rivers! The Yellow River, or Huang He, gets its name because it carries golden dirt called silt, which makes the land around it perfect for growing yummy food. Then there's the Yangtze River, which is incredibly long and flows through the middle of China, helping farmers grow even more food.

slides.prompt: On your blank map of China, draw and label: the Yellow River (Huang He), the Yangtze River, the Himalayas, the Gobi Desert, the Tibetan Plateau, the Pacific Ocean, and where the Great Wall runs. Color-code by elevation: green for lowlands, brown for mountains, tan for desert, blue for water.
slides.mascot_explanation: Alright, it's your turn to be the map maker! On your blank map, you're going to carefully draw and label the Yellow River, the Yangtze River, the giant Himalayas, the big Gobi Desert, the high Tibetan Plateau, the big Pacific Ocean, and where the Great Wall of China is. Then, use your colored pencils to color the land by its height: green for low parts, brown for mountains, yellow-tan for the desert, and blue for the water.

slides.text: China's geography made it like a natural fortress — protected by mountains, desert, and ocean. The two great rivers provided water and rich soil for farming. This is why Chinese civilization developed somewhat separately from the rest of the world.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student identify and locate the Yellow River, Yangtze River, Himalayas, Gobi Desert, and Pacific Ocean on a map of China?
slides.mascot_explanation: You did it! You've made an amazing map showing all of China's incredible features. Remember how the tall mountains, the huge desert, and the big ocean acted like a natural wall, keeping China protected? And how those two giant rivers gave people water and rich soil to grow food? That's why China's culture grew in its own special way!

parent_notes: China's geography is key to understanding its history. The natural barriers explain why the Great Wall was only needed along the northern border — the other sides were already protected. Compare China's rivers to the Nile, Tigris, and Euphrates. All ancient civilizations grew up along rivers. China has the largest population of any country (about 1.4 billion people), mostly concentrated in the eastern lowlands near the rivers.

title: Read Aloud — The Story of the Great Wall
description: A read-aloud session about the Great Wall of China, connecting to the history and geography lessons. Students listen, discuss, and respond to the text through conversation and illustration.
instructions:
1. Choose a read-aloud book about the Great Wall (suggestions: 'The Great Wall of China' by Leonard Everett Fisher, or a similar age-appropriate text).
2. Before reading: activate prior knowledge from today's lessons. 'What do we already know about the Great Wall?'
3. Read the text aloud, pausing for discussion at key points.
4. After reading: discuss new information learned. What surprised them?
5. Students write a short journal response: 'If I could walk along the Great Wall, I would see...'
6. Share responses aloud.
materials_needed: Book about the Great Wall of China

slides.heading: Read Aloud
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is like the cover page of our adventure today! It tells us we're going to do a read-aloud, and our special topic is the amazing Great Wall of China. Get ready to learn something super interesting!

slides.setup_instructions: Select an age-appropriate book about the Great Wall. Preview it and mark good stopping points for discussion.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, for this part, we need a few things to make our read-aloud super fun. First, find that book all about the Great Wall – that's our main story! Then, grab your special reading journal and some pencils, including colored ones, so you can draw a picture later.

slides.text: Before reading: 'We learned about the Great Wall today in history and geography. What do you remember? Why was it built? How long is it?' Let the child share what they recall.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's time to think like detectives! Remember how we talked about the Great Wall in our history and geography lessons? What can you tell me about it? Why do you think people built such a giant wall, and how long do you think it is? Let's hear what you remember!

slides.text: Read the book aloud with expression. Pause at key moments: 'Can you imagine carrying heavy stones up these steep mountains? What would that feel like?' Connect illustrations to what they learned earlier.
slides.mascot_explanation: This is where the magic happens – we get to read the story! I'll read the book aloud, and I want you to listen carefully and look at the pictures. We'll stop sometimes to talk about cool parts, like how difficult it must have been to build such a huge wall on tall mountains!

slides.text: After reading: 'What new facts did you learn from this book that we did not cover in our lesson? What was the most surprising thing?' Discuss.
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, we just finished the story! What amazing new things did you learn about the Great Wall from the book that we didn't talk about before? Was there anything that really surprised you or made you go "Whoa!"? Let's chat about it!

slides.prompt: In your reading journal, write a short paragraph beginning with: 'If I could walk along the Great Wall, I would see...' Include at least three details from today's lessons and the book. Add an illustration.
slides.mascot_explanation: Alright, now it's your turn to be the storyteller! Open your reading journal and start your sentence with "If I could walk along the Great Wall, I would see..." Try to include at least three interesting things you learned from our lesson and the book, and then draw a picture of what you imagine!

slides.text: Great writing! The Great Wall is a symbol of human determination and ingenuity. This week we will continue exploring Ancient China and discover even more amazing achievements.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student recall key facts from the read-aloud and connect them to prior learning about the Great Wall?
slides.mascot_explanation: You did such a fantastic job writing and drawing today! You learned so many cool facts about the Great Wall and even remembered what we talked about before. The Great Wall really shows how people can do incredible things when they work together, just like we did today!

parent_notes: Read-alouds that connect to other subjects reinforce learning powerfully. If you cannot find a specific Great Wall book, search your library for any age-appropriate book about Ancient China. Online read-alouds on educational channels can also work. The journal writing connects literacy with history content.

title: Sentence Types — Imperative and Exclamatory
description: Students learn the remaining two sentence types: imperative (commands/requests) and exclamatory (strong feelings). They practice identifying all four types and using appropriate end punctuation.
instructions:
1. Review declarative and interrogative from yesterday.
2. Introduce imperative: 'Close the door.' 'Please pass the salt.' These are commands or requests.
3. Note: imperative sentences can end with a period or exclamation point depending on urgency.
4. Introduce exclamatory: 'What an amazing wall that is!' 'I can not believe how long it is!' These express strong emotion.
5. Always end with an exclamation point.
6. Practice: give 12 sentences for students to classify as declarative, interrogative, imperative, or exclamatory.
7. Students write 2 of each type, all related to Ancient China.

slides.heading: Types of Sentences
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is like the cover of our book today! It tells us we're going to learn about different kinds of sentences, specifically two new ones called "imperative" and "exclamatory." It's like learning new ways to talk and write!

slides.setup_instructions: Prepare 12 sentence cards (3 of each type). Make four labeled sorting areas on the table.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, let's get our tools ready for some sentence fun! We need a whiteboard and markers to write on, our special grammar journal to keep our work safe, pencils for writing, and 12 little cards with sentences on them. We'll also need to make four spots on the table, one for each type of sentence we're learning about.

slides.text: Quick review: 'What are the two sentence types we learned yesterday?' Declarative = statement (period). Interrogative = question (question mark). 'Today we learn the last two!'
slides.mascot_explanation: This step is a quick reminder of what we learned yesterday. Remember how some sentences just tell you something, like "The sky is blue," and they end with a period? And others ask a question, like "What time is it?" and they end with a question mark? Well, today we're going to learn the other two kinds!

slides.text: 'Listen: Build the wall higher! Bring more stones! These sentences give commands — they tell someone to DO something. We call them imperative sentences. The subject (you) is usually hidden.' Write examples on the board.
slides.mascot_explanation: Listen to this: "Build the wall higher!" or "Bring more stones!" Do you hear how those sentences are telling someone what to do? Those are called imperative sentences, and they're like giving a command or making a request. It's like when your grown-up tells you, "Please clean your room!"

slides.text: 'Now listen: The Great Wall is absolutely incredible! I cannot believe it is 13,000 miles long! These express STRONG feelings — excitement, surprise, amazement. We call them exclamatory sentences. They always end with an exclamation point!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, imagine someone seeing the Great Wall of China for the first time and shouting, "Wow, that wall is amazing!" or "I can't believe how long it is!" Those sentences show big feelings, like excitement or surprise. We call those exclamatory sentences, and they always end with a special mark that looks like a little stick with a dot, called an exclamation point!

slides.prompt: Sort the 12 sentence cards into four categories: declarative, interrogative, imperative, and exclamatory. Then write 2 sentences of each type (8 total) about Ancient China in your journal. Use correct end punctuation!
slides.mascot_explanation: Alright, this is where we get to be sentence detectives! We'll take those 12 sentence cards and sort them into four piles: statements, questions, commands, and sentences with big feelings. After we sort them, you'll get to write your own sentences about Ancient China, two of each kind, using the right ending marks.

slides.text: Now you know all four sentence types! Declarative tells (.), interrogative asks (?), imperative commands (. or !), and exclamatory shows strong feeling (!). Good writers use all four to make their writing interesting.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student identify and write all four sentence types with correct punctuation?
slides.mascot_explanation: Hooray, you did it! You now know all four types of sentences: statements that tell us things, questions that ask things, commands that tell someone what to do, and exclamatory sentences that show big feelings. Using all these different kinds of sentences will make your own writing super interesting, just like a good story!

parent_notes: All four sentence types are now introduced. Over the coming days, encourage your child to identify sentence types in their reading. Play a game: read a passage and have them raise one finger for declarative, two for interrogative, three for imperative, and four for exclamatory. This builds automatic recognition.

title: Decimals — Comparing and Ordering Decimals
description: Students learn to compare decimals using place value understanding. They use hundred grids and number lines to visualize which decimal is greater and practice using the symbols <, >, and =.
instructions:
1. Review hundredths with the hundred grid.
2. Present two decimals: 0.3 and 0.25. Ask: 'Which is larger?'
3. Common mistake: students think 0.25 > 0.3 because 25 > 3. Show with grids: 0.3 = 30 hundredths, 0.25 = 25 hundredths.
4. Strategy: make both decimals have the same number of places (0.30 vs. 0.25).
5. Use a number line from 0 to 1 divided into hundredths to place decimals.
6. Practice: compare 10 pairs of decimals using <, >, =.
7. Order sets of 4-5 decimals from least to greatest.
materials_needed: Number line (0 to 1, marked in hundredths)

slides.heading: Comparing Decimals
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is like the title of our game today! It's called "Comparing Decimals," and it's all about figuring out which numbers with dots (decimals!) are bigger or smaller. We're going to become super detectives and solve the mystery of "Which Is Greater?"

slides.setup_instructions: Draw a large number line from 0 to 1 on the board, marked at every tenth. Have hundred grids ready for visual comparison.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, this is our "tool chest" for today's math adventure! We have these cool square grids called "hundred grids" – imagine a big square cut into 100 tiny squares, perfect for seeing parts of a whole. We also have a number line, which is like a ruler for numbers, going from 0 all the way to 1. You'll also see some cards with symbols like >, <, and = – these are our "greater than," "less than," and "equal to" signs. And we'll use the whiteboard and a practice sheet to do our work.

slides.text: 'Which is larger: 0.3 or 0.25? Think carefully before you answer.' Many children say 0.25 because 25 is bigger than 3. Shade both on hundred grids to see the truth: 0.3 = 30 squares, 0.25 = 25 squares. '0.3 is actually larger!'
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide is showing us a tricky problem! It asks which is bigger, 0.3 or 0.25. Some people might think 0.25 is bigger because 25 is a bigger number than 3, right? But watch this: if we color in 0.3 on our hundred grid, it's like coloring 30 little squares. And 0.25 is only 25 little squares. So, 0.3 is actually bigger!

slides.text: 'Here is a trick: make both numbers have the same number of decimal places. 0.3 becomes 0.30. Now compare 0.30 and 0.25. Since 30 hundredths > 25 hundredths, 0.30 > 0.25. Always compare place by place: tenths first, then hundredths.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Here's a super helpful trick for comparing decimals! See how 0.3 only has a number in the tenths place, but 0.25 has numbers in both the tenths and hundredths places? We can make them match by adding a zero to the end of 0.3, making it 0.30. Now we can easily see that 0.30 is bigger than 0.25 because we're comparing 30 hundredths to 25 hundredths. Always try to make your decimals the same length!

slides.text: Place several decimals on the number line: 0.1, 0.45, 0.7, 0.05, 0.99. 'See how they spread out? Numbers further to the right are larger.' Practice comparing pairs using <, >, and = symbols.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we're using our number line, which is like a road for numbers! We're going to put different decimals on it, like 0.1, 0.45, and 0.99. See how they get placed further along the line? Numbers that are further to the right on the number line are always the bigger numbers. We'll use our special symbol cards to show which number is greater than, less than, or equal to another number.

slides.prompt: Compare 10 pairs of decimals using <, >, or =. Then order these sets from least to greatest: (a) 0.5, 0.05, 0.50, 0.55; (b) 0.8, 0.18, 0.81, 0.08; (c) 0.3, 0.33, 0.03, 0.30.
slides.mascot_explanation: Get ready for some fun practice! You're going to compare 10 pairs of decimals using our greater than (>), less than (<), and equal to (=) signs. After that, you'll get to arrange some groups of decimals from the smallest to the largest, like putting them in order for a race! Just remember to look at the numbers in the same place value spots to help you.

slides.text: When comparing decimals, always look at the tenths place first. If those are equal, look at the hundredths place. You can add a zero to make decimals the same length: 0.3 = 0.30. This does not change the value!
slides.mastery_check: Can the student correctly compare and order decimals to the hundredths place?
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, you did it! You learned how to be a decimal detective and figure out which numbers are bigger and smaller. Remember, the best way to compare them is to look at the tenths place first, and if they're the same, then look at the hundredths place. Adding a zero at the end, like changing 0.3 to 0.30, is a super smart trick that helps a lot! You're getting so good at this!

parent_notes: The key misconception to watch for is thinking that more digits after the decimal point means a larger number (e.g., thinking 0.25 > 0.3). The hundred grid is the best tool to combat this. Practice with money: 'Is $0.30 more than $0.25?' Children who understand money often grasp this more quickly.

title: Invertebrates — Introduction to Insects
description: Students begin studying invertebrates by exploring insects. They learn the three body parts (head, thorax, abdomen), six legs, and other defining characteristics that make an animal an insect.
instructions:
1. Review: 'We studied vertebrates — animals with backbones. Now we study INvertebrates — animals WITHOUT backbones. Most animals on Earth are invertebrates!'
2. Focus on insects: the largest group of invertebrates.
3. Show a diagram of an insect body: head (antennae, eyes, mouthparts), thorax (6 legs, wings), abdomen.
4. Key rule: if it has 3 body parts and 6 legs, it is an insect.
5. Sort pictures: is it an insect or not? (butterfly yes, spider no — 8 legs, worm no — no legs).
6. Students draw and label a detailed insect diagram.
7. Discuss: why are insects so successful? (small, reproduce quickly, can fly, diverse diets).
materials_needed: Pictures of various insects and non-insects for sorting

slides.heading: Invertebrates
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is like the title page for our new adventure! It's telling us we're going to learn all about "Invertebrates," which are animals without a backbone, and we're going to start with the super cool group called "Insects."

slides.setup_instructions: Print the insect anatomy diagram large enough to study. Prepare 15-20 pictures of animals to sort: 10 insects, 5-10 non-insects (spiders, centipedes, worms, crabs).
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, this slide shows us all the cool tools we'll be using for our insect investigation! We have a diagram to help us see an insect's body parts, pictures to sort, a magnifying glass to look super close, and paper and colored pencils to make our own drawings. Go grab all these things with a grown-up so we can get started!

slides.text: 'We spent weeks studying vertebrates — fish, amphibians, reptiles, birds, and mammals. But did you know that 97% of all animal species are INvertebrates — animals WITHOUT a backbone? Today we start with the biggest group of all: INSECTS!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Remember how we learned about animals with backbones, like puppies and fish? Well, this slide is introducing us to the opposite: invertebrates, animals that *don't* have a backbone, and guess what? Most animals on Earth are invertebrates, and we're going to focus on the biggest group of them all – insects!

slides.text: Show the insect diagram. 'Every insect has THREE body sections: the HEAD (with eyes, antennae, and mouth), the THORAX (the middle section where the 6 legs and wings attach), and the ABDOMEN (the back section that holds the digestive and reproductive organs).'
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide is like a close-up look at what makes an insect an insect! It shows us that every insect has three main body parts: a head, which has their eyes and feelers called antennae; a thorax, which is like the middle part where their legs and wings attach; and an abdomen, which is the back part. Isn't it neat how their bodies are put together?

slides.text: 'The golden rule: 3 body parts + 6 legs = insect. A spider has 8 legs — NOT an insect. A centipede has many legs — NOT an insect. A worm has no legs — NOT an insect.' Sort the pictures together, counting legs and body parts.
slides.mascot_explanation: Here's the super important clue for figuring out if something is an insect: if it has exactly three body parts and six legs, then it's an insect! This slide reminds us that spiders have eight legs, and worms don't have any legs, so they aren't insects, even though they are also invertebrates. We'll use this rule to sort our pictures!

slides.prompt: Draw a large, detailed insect and label: head, thorax, abdomen, antennae, compound eyes, 6 legs (attached to thorax), wings. Then sort the remaining pictures into 'insect' and 'not an insect' piles, explaining your reasoning for each.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's your turn to be an insect expert and artist! You get to draw your very own insect, making sure to show its head, thorax, and abdomen, plus its antennae and six legs. After your amazing drawing, you'll sort the rest of the animal pictures into two groups: insects and not-insects, and you can tell me why you chose each spot!

slides.text: Insects are the most successful animals on Earth — there are over one million known species! They live on every continent except Antarctica. Remember: 3 body parts, 6 legs, and usually wings. Next time, we will explore insect life cycles.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student identify the three body parts of an insect and distinguish insects from other arthropods?
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, you did it! We learned that insects are super successful animals because there are so many of them and they live all over the world. You can now remember that the secret code for an insect is three body parts and six legs, and you even drew and sorted them like a real scientist!

parent_notes: Invertebrate study is a natural next step after vertebrates. Children are often fascinated by insects. Go on a bug hunt in your yard — use a magnifying glass to count legs and body sections on any insects you find. Remind your child that spiders are NOT insects (they are arachnids). This is a common misconception even among adults.

title: Chinese Art — Brush Painting (Ink Wash)
description: Students explore traditional Chinese brush painting (ink wash painting or sumi-e). They learn about the Four Treasures of the Study and practice basic brush strokes to create bamboo or orchid paintings.
instructions:
1. Introduce Chinese brush painting: one of the oldest art traditions, dating back thousands of years.
2. Explain the Four Treasures of the Study: brush, ink, paper, and inkstone.
3. Demonstrate how to hold the brush vertically (different from Western painting).
4. Show basic strokes: the dot, the horizontal stroke, the vertical stroke, the curve.
5. Practice strokes on scrap paper.
6. Guide students through painting bamboo: straight trunk strokes, angled branch strokes, leaf strokes.
7. Let students create their own bamboo painting on rice paper or watercolor paper.
8. Discuss how this connects to Ancient China.
materials_needed: Rice paper or white watercolor paper

slides.heading: Chinese Art
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is like the cover of our adventure book! It's showing us that we're going to learn about art from China, and not just any art, but a special kind called "Brush Painting," which is also sometimes called "Ink Wash." It's super old and really cool!

slides.setup_instructions: Cover the workspace. Pre-mix ink to various dilutions (dark, medium, light) in separate containers. Have example paintings displayed.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, this slide shows us all the special tools we'll need for our Chinese art project. We have black ink or watercolor paint, some round brushes that are perfect for this kind of painting, special paper called rice paper or even watercolor paper, little cups for water, and paper towels for oopsies. There are also some pictures of real Chinese paintings to give us ideas. Make sure you have all these things ready with a grown-up!

slides.text: 'In Ancient China, painting was one of the most respected arts. Chinese artists used the Four Treasures of the Study: a brush, ink, paper, and an inkstone for grinding ink. Today we will paint in the Chinese style!'
slides.mascot_explanation: This is like our first secret from the ancient Chinese artists! They thought painting was super important, and they had four special things they always used, called the "Four Treasures." We'll be using a brush, ink, and paper, just like they did way back then. Today, we're going to learn their amazing painting style!

slides.text: 'Chinese brushes are held straight up, not at an angle like Western pencils. This gives you more control.' Demonstrate: hold the brush vertically, use the whole arm to move. Show how pressing harder makes thick lines, and barely touching makes thin lines.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, let's learn a special trick for holding our brush! Instead of holding it sideways like we might hold a crayon, we're going to hold it straight up and down, like we're pointing to the sky. This way, we can make really thin lines by just touching the paper lightly, or nice thick lines if we press down a little more. We'll move our whole arm, not just our wrist, to make the paint dance on the paper!

slides.text: 'We will paint bamboo — one of the most popular subjects in Chinese art. The straight trunk is just a series of segments.' Demonstrate: quick, confident strokes for the trunk. Thin branches at angles. Quick flicks for leaves. 'Speed and confidence are more important than perfection!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Get ready to paint bamboo! Bamboo is a really popular thing for Chinese artists to paint because it’s strong but also bends in the wind. We'll make the bamboo trunk with straight, quick strokes, add some branches that stick out at angles, and then use fast little flicks of the brush to make the leaves. Remember, the artists in China thought being quick and sure was more important than making it look perfectly neat!

slides.prompt: Practice the basic strokes on scrap paper first. Then create your own bamboo painting on good paper. Try varying your ink from dark to light by adding more water. Add a few leaves using quick, confident flicks of the brush.
slides.mascot_explanation: This is the super fun part where you get to be the artist! First, grab some scrap paper and try out those different strokes we learned – straight lines, curves, and those quick flicks for leaves. Then, take your nice paper and create your very own bamboo picture, maybe using the dark ink for some parts and lighter ink for others. Don't be afraid to make lots of leaves with fast flicks!

slides.text: In Chinese culture, bamboo represents strength and flexibility — it bends in the wind but does not break. Chinese artists often paint bamboo to express these qualities. Your paintings capture the spirit of an art form that is over 2,000 years old!
slides.mastery_check: Can the student hold the brush vertically and create basic Chinese brush painting strokes to compose a simple bamboo painting?
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at what you've made! You just created your own Chinese brush painting, just like artists did thousands of years ago. Remember how bamboo stands strong but can bend? That's what your painting shows, and you learned how to hold the brush and make those special strokes. You totally captured the spirit of this ancient art!

parent_notes: Chinese brush painting is a wonderful complement to the Ancient China history lessons. The key technique is holding the brush vertically and using confident, quick strokes rather than careful, slow ones. If rice paper is unavailable, regular watercolor paper works. Emphasize that in Chinese art, empty space is just as important as the painted areas.

title: Tea Ceremony — Chinese Tea Preparation
description: Students learn about the Chinese tea ceremony and practice preparing and serving tea with grace and care. This connects to the Ancient China unit while developing practical life skills of pouring, serving, and hospitality.
instructions:
1. Discuss the history of tea: discovered in China around 2737 BCE according to legend.
2. Show the materials: teapot, cups, tea leaves (or herbal tea bags for children), hot water.
3. Demonstrate: warm the pot and cups with a little hot water first, add tea, pour water, wait.
4. Teach proper pouring: hold the pot lid with one finger, pour slowly and steadily.
5. Serving etiquette: offer to others before serving yourself, hold the cup with both hands.
6. Students prepare and serve tea, practicing careful pouring and polite manners.
7. Clean up: wash and dry all materials, put everything away.

slides.heading: Practical Life
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is like the title page for our fun activity! It's called "Practical Life" and we're going to learn about the "Chinese Tea Ceremony." Think of it like learning a special, calm way to prepare and share a drink.

slides.setup_instructions: Heat water ahead of time. Arrange all materials on a tray. Use herbal tea like chamomile or peppermint (no caffeine for children).
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, let's get ready! We need a small teapot, which is like a special pitcher for tea, and some little cups to drink from. We'll use herbal tea, which is made from plants and won't keep you awake, and we'll need hot water, but remember, a grown-up *always* has to help with that part! We'll put everything on a tray with a little towel, just in case.

slides.text: 'Tea was discovered in Ancient China! Legend says Emperor Shen Nung was sitting under a tea tree when leaves blew into his hot water. He tasted it and loved it. Tea became one of China's greatest gifts to the world. Today we will prepare and serve tea the Chinese way.'
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide tells us a cool story about how tea was first discovered a super long time ago in China! Legend says a king was resting and some leaves fell into his hot water, and he discovered how yummy it was. Now, we get to learn how to prepare tea the special Chinese way, which is a really thoughtful thing to do.

slides.text: 'First, we warm the pot and cups. Pour a little hot water in, swirl it around, and pour it out. This prepares the vessels and keeps the tea warm longer.' Demonstrate slowly and carefully. 'Now add the tea leaves (or bag) and pour in the hot water. We wait patiently for it to steep.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we're going to get the teapot and cups ready. First, we pour a little bit of the hot water into the teapot and cups, swirl it around like a mini whirlpool, and then pour that water out. This is like giving them a warm hug to get them ready! Then, we'll put the tea inside, pour the rest of the hot water in, and wait a little bit for the tea to get its flavor, kind of like letting cookies bake.

slides.text: 'When pouring, hold the lid with one finger and pour slowly and steadily. Fill each cup only about three-quarters full. In Chinese tradition, you always serve others before yourself. Hold your cup with both hands to show respect and appreciation.'
slides.mascot_explanation: This is about how to be a super polite tea server! When you pour, hold the lid down gently with one finger so it doesn't fall off, and tip the teapot just a little bit so the tea flows out in a slow, steady stream, like a tiny waterfall. Remember to only fill the cups about three-quarters full, and it's important to offer the tea to others before you pour for yourself.

slides.prompt: Prepare tea following the steps demonstrated. Pour carefully for each person, serving others first. Sit quietly and enjoy your tea, practicing holding the cup with both hands. When finished, wash and dry all the tea materials and put them away.
slides.mascot_explanation: Alright, it's your turn to be the tea master! Carefully follow the steps we just learned to prepare the tea. Then, pour it gently for everyone else first, remembering to hold the cup with both hands when you offer it to them, like you're giving a special gift. After we enjoy our tea, we'll wash everything up nicely and put it all away, just like real helpers do.

slides.text: Tea preparation teaches us patience, care, and hospitality. In China, serving tea is a way of showing respect and building friendships. You practiced pouring carefully, serving others first, and cleaning up — all important life skills!
slides.mastery_check: Can the student safely prepare and pour tea, demonstrate serving etiquette, and clean up all materials?
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, you did such a great job preparing and serving tea! That was a wonderful way to practice being patient and showing kindness to others, which is what hospitality means. You learned how to pour carefully, serve your friends and family first, and clean up everything like a pro!

parent_notes: This practical life activity beautifully integrates with the Ancient China unit. Always supervise hot water handling. Use caffeine-free herbal tea. The emphasis on serving others first and holding cups with both hands teaches grace and courtesy — core Montessori values. If you have any Chinese tea accessories (gaiwan, small cups), use them for authenticity.

title: Creative Writing — Planning a Short Story
description: Students learn the elements of a short story (character, setting, problem, solution) and plan their own original short story using a story map graphic organizer. The story will be written over several sessions.
instructions:
1. Discuss: 'What makes a story a story?' It needs characters, a setting, a problem, and a solution.
2. Use a familiar story as an example — break it into these four elements.
3. Introduce the story map: a graphic organizer with boxes for Character, Setting, Problem, Events (beginning, middle, end), and Solution.
4. Brainstorm story ideas together — encourage China-inspired themes but allow any topic.
5. Students complete their story map, planning each element.
6. Share story plans with a partner or parent.
7. Explain: tomorrow they will begin writing the actual story.

slides.heading: Creative Writing
slides.mascot_explanation: Hey there! This first slide is like the title page for our adventure. It tells us we're going to be doing some creative writing, and the special kind of writing we're planning today is a short story! Think of it like building with words.

slides.setup_instructions: Print story map templates. Have a completed example story map to show as a model.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, this slide shows us all the cool tools we need for our story-building project. We've got a story map, which is like a treasure map for your ideas, a writing journal and pencils for writing everything down, and a whiteboard for sharing our awesome ideas together. Make sure you have all these things ready to go!

slides.text: 'Every great story has four key ingredients: CHARACTERS (who is it about?), SETTING (where and when does it happen?), PROBLEM (what goes wrong or what challenge do they face?), and SOLUTION (how is the problem solved?). Let us look at a story we know and find these ingredients.'
slides.mascot_explanation: This is super important for understanding how stories work! The slide tells us that every good story needs four main parts: characters, which are the people or animals in the story; the setting, which is where and when the story happens; a problem, which is something tricky that needs to be solved; and a solution, which is how the character fixes the problem.

slides.text: Use a familiar story (fairy tale or recently-read book) and identify each element together. Write them on the board. 'See? Every story follows this pattern. Even movies and TV shows have these same ingredients!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we get to see how those four parts work in a story we already know! We'll pick a story, maybe a fairy tale or a book we just read, and find the characters, the setting, the problem, and the solution together. It's like being a detective and finding clues in the story!

slides.text: 'Now it is YOUR turn to plan an original story! Use this story map to organize your ideas. You might write about an adventure on the Great Wall, or a journey along the Silk Road, or anything you wish! First, decide on your character and setting, then think of an interesting problem.'
slides.mascot_explanation: It's your turn to become a story creator! This slide is showing you your special planning tool, the story map. You'll use this to plan out your very own original story, thinking about who your character is, where they live, and what exciting problem they will face.

slides.prompt: Complete your story map: describe your main character (name, age, personality), your setting (where and when), the problem they face, 3 main events (beginning, middle, end), and how the problem is solved. Be as detailed as you can — this is your blueprint!
slides.mascot_explanation: This is where the real magic happens! You get to fill out your story map with all your amazing ideas. Think about your character, where they are, what goes wrong, what happens next, and how it all gets fixed. The more details you add, the better your story will be – it's like drawing the plan before you build a LEGO castle!

slides.text: Share your story plan! Great writers always plan before they write. Your story map is like an architect's blueprint — it shows you what to build. Tomorrow we will start writing the actual story using this plan as our guide.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student plan a short story with identifiable characters, setting, problem, and solution using a graphic organizer?
slides.mascot_explanation: We did it! You've planned out your whole story, from beginning to end, with characters, a setting, a problem, and a solution. Your story map is like a secret guide that will help you write your amazing story tomorrow. Great job being a super planner!

parent_notes: Story planning is a crucial writing skill. Many children want to jump straight into writing, but planning produces much better stories. The story map acts as a scaffold. Do not worry about perfection at this stage — the goal is to generate ideas and organize them. The actual writing will happen in upcoming sessions. Encourage creative and original ideas rather than retelling known stories.

title: Decimals — Addition of Decimals
description: Students learn to add decimals by lining up the decimal points. They use hundred grids for visual support and practice adding tenths and hundredths with and without regrouping.
instructions:
1. Review: adding whole numbers — we line up the ones, tens, hundreds. With decimals, we line up the DECIMAL POINTS.
2. Demonstrate: 0.3 + 0.4. Shade 30 squares, then shade 40 more squares on the same grid = 70 squares = 0.7.
3. Demonstrate with column addition: write vertically, line up decimal points, add column by column.
4. Practice: 0.25 + 0.13 = ? Shade and add. Line up and add. Both methods give 0.38.
5. With regrouping: 0.47 + 0.35 = ? 7 hundredths + 5 hundredths = 12 hundredths = 1 tenth and 2 hundredths.
6. Practice set of 8 problems, increasing difficulty.
7. Word problems involving money as decimals.

slides.heading: Adding Decimals
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is like a welcome mat for our new math adventure! It's telling us we're going to learn how to add decimals, and the most important trick is remembering to line up the little dots, called decimal points. It’s like making sure all the numbers are standing in a straight line before we add them up!

slides.setup_instructions: Print plenty of hundred grids. Have two different colored pencils ready for shading the two addends in different colors.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, let's get our tools ready for some super cool math! We've got these grids that look like tiny checkerboards—they help us see decimals. Then we have two different colored pencils so we can color in different numbers without getting mixed up. We'll also use a whiteboard to practice writing, and a special place value chart to help us remember where each number goes, like tens, ones, and those tiny decimal parts.

slides.text: 'When we add whole numbers, we line up the ones place. When we add decimals, we line up the DECIMAL POINTS.' Write 0.3 + 0.4 vertically on the board with decimal points aligned. 'Then we add each column just like we always do.'
slides.mascot_explanation: This step is super important for adding decimals! Remember how when we add big numbers, we line up the ones, then the tens, and so on? With decimals, it's almost the same, but we make sure those little decimal points are lined up perfectly in a row. Then, we just add up the numbers in each column, just like we always do, and the answer will come out right!

slides.text: Show on the hundred grid: shade 30 squares in blue (0.3), then shade 40 more in red (0.4). Count total: 70 squares = 0.7. 'See how the grid matches our column addition? Both give us 0.7!' Now try 0.25 + 0.13 with both methods.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we get to see how it all works together! We'll color in parts of our grid to show the first number, like 30 little squares for 0.3. Then, we'll use another color to add more squares for the second number, like 40 more for 0.4. When we count all the colored squares, it shows us the answer, and you'll see it matches what we get when we add the numbers the normal way, lining up those decimal points!

slides.text: 'What about 0.47 + 0.35? In the hundredths column: 7 + 5 = 12. That is more than 9, so we regroup! 12 hundredths = 1 tenth and 2 hundredths. Carry the 1 to the tenths column: 4 + 3 + 1 = 8 tenths. Answer: 0.82.' Verify with the grid.
slides.mascot_explanation: Sometimes, when we add the numbers in a column, we get a number bigger than 9, like 7 plus 5 makes 12. That's when we need to "regroup," which just means we carry over that extra '1' to the next column, just like we do with regular adding. So, 7 hundredths and 5 hundredths makes 12 hundredths, which is 1 tenth and 2 hundredths, and we carry that tenth over to join the other tenths.

slides.prompt: Solve these decimal addition problems, lining up the decimal points: (1) 0.6 + 0.3, (2) 0.14 + 0.25, (3) 0.38 + 0.41, (4) 0.56 + 0.27, (5) 0.75 + 0.18, (6) 0.9 + 0.45. Use hundred grids to check at least 3 of your answers.
slides.mascot_explanation: Get ready to try some on your own! You'll get to practice adding different decimal numbers. Remember the super trick: line up those decimal points first! If you want to double-check your work, you can use those cool hundred grids and colored pencils to see if your answer is right. You’ve got this!

slides.text: The key to adding decimals: line up the decimal points, then add just like whole numbers. If you have different numbers of decimal places, add a zero to make them match (0.9 = 0.90). Regrouping works the same way as with whole numbers.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student add decimals to the hundredths place, including problems that require regrouping?
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, you did it! You learned how to add decimals by lining up those decimal points, just like a super organized math detective. We saw how coloring in grids helped us see the answer and how carrying over numbers, or regrouping, works the same way it does with whole numbers. You're becoming a decimal whiz!

parent_notes: Decimal addition follows the same rules as whole number addition — the only new concept is lining up the decimal points. Money is a perfect real-world connection: $0.75 + $0.18 = $0.93. Practice with coins and prices during shopping trips. The hundred grid provides a visual check: shade one addend, shade the other, count the total.

title: Ancient China — The Silk Road
description: Students learn about the Silk Road trade network that connected China to the Mediterranean world. They explore what was traded, how goods traveled, and how ideas and cultures spread along the route.
instructions:
1. Review: 'China had the Great Wall to protect its borders. But China also traded with the outside world. How?'
2. Introduce the Silk Road: not one road but a network of routes stretching 4,000 miles.
3. Show the route on a map: from Chang'an (Xi'an) in China across Central Asia to Rome.
4. What was traded: silk, spices, tea, porcelain FROM China; gold, glass, horses, wool TO China.
5. Discuss: traders did not usually travel the whole route. Goods passed through many hands.
6. Cultural exchange: religions (Buddhism), inventions, foods, and languages spread along the road.
7. Students trace the Silk Road on a map and draw pictures of traded goods at each end.
materials_needed: Sample materials if available (silk fabric, spices)
Yarn or string to trace the route on a wall map

slides.heading: Ancient China
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is like the cover of our book about ancient China! It's introducing us to a super important part of their history called the Silk Road.

items: Sample silk fabric and spices (if available)
slides.setup_instructions: Display a large map of Eurasia. Have yarn ready to trace the Silk Road route. If possible, bring silk fabric and spices for children to touch and smell.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, this slide shows us all the cool stuff we'll need for our adventure! We have a big map to see where things are, some yarn to show us a special path, and paper and pencils for drawing. If we have real silk or spices, we can even touch and smell them to imagine what it was like back then!

slides.text: 'China had something the rest of the world wanted desperately: SILK. This beautiful, shiny fabric came from silkworms, and only the Chinese knew how to make it. People in Rome, Persia, and India would pay a fortune for silk. But how did it get there?'
slides.mascot_explanation: This part is like a riddle! It tells us that people in ancient China made something amazing called silk, which was super shiny and soft. Everyone far away wanted it, but how did they get it all the way to places like Rome?

slides.text: 'The Silk Road! It was not one road but a whole network of paths stretching over 4,000 miles — from China all the way to Rome.' Trace the route on the map with yarn. 'It crossed deserts, mountain passes, and grasslands. The journey could take over a year!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Get ready to see the path! This isn't just one road, but lots of paths all connected, like a giant spiderweb across the land, going all the way from China to Rome. Imagine traveling for more than a whole year on bumpy roads, through deserts and mountains, just to trade!

slides.text: 'Traders did not just carry silk. From China: silk, tea, spices, porcelain, paper, and gunpowder. From the West: gold, silver, glass, horses, and wool. Along with goods, IDEAS traveled too — religions like Buddhism, new inventions, and different foods spread along the Silk Road.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at all the treasures! China sent out beautiful silk, yummy spices, and delicate teacups, but they also got cool things like shiny gold and strong horses from the other side of the world. Even more exciting, they shared ideas, like stories about new gods and even how to make things, which is pretty neat!

slides.prompt: On your map, trace the Silk Road route from Chang'an to Rome. At the China end, draw and label 5 goods that traveled westward. At the Rome end, draw and label 5 goods that traveled eastward. In the middle, write 'IDEAS' and list 3 things that spread along the road.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's your turn to be a Silk Road explorer! Grab your map and yarn to show the path, then draw what China sent out and what they got back. Don't forget to write down the amazing ideas that traveled along the way in the middle!

slides.text: The Silk Road was one of history's most important trade routes. It connected East and West, allowing not just goods but ideas, religions, and inventions to spread across continents. Even today, we benefit from the cultural exchange that happened along the Silk Road.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student describe the Silk Road, identify goods traded in both directions, and trace the general route on a map?
slides.mascot_explanation: We did it! We learned all about the Silk Road, how people and goods traveled super far, and how they even shared new ideas and foods. It's amazing to think how this one path helped connect so many different people and places a long, long time ago.

parent_notes: The Silk Road is a fascinating topic because it shows how interconnected the ancient world really was. If possible, let your child feel real silk and smell spices like cinnamon and pepper — these were among the most valuable trade goods. The concept of cultural exchange (ideas traveling along with goods) is an important one for children to understand.

title: Chinese Inventions — Paper and Printing
description: Students learn about two of China's Four Great Inventions: papermaking and printing. They explore how these inventions changed the world and try making simple paper or printing with carved stamps.
instructions:
1. Ask: 'What do you write on? Where does paper come from?'
2. Before paper: people wrote on bamboo strips, silk, clay tablets, papyrus. All had drawbacks.
3. Cai Lun (105 CE) invented paper from bark, rags, and plant fibers. Revolutionary!
4. Later, the Chinese invented woodblock printing: carve text backwards into a block, ink it, press onto paper.
5. Even later: movable type — individual character stamps that could be rearranged.
6. Discuss impact: books could be made faster and cheaper. Knowledge spread!
7. Activity: students make simple prints using carved potatoes or foam stamps.
materials_needed: Potatoes (halved) or foam blocks for carving stamps
Examples of different writing surfaces (if available)

slides.heading: Chinese Inventions
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide is showing us the topic of our lesson today: amazing inventions from China called paper and printing! Think about all the cool things we write on and read from – well, a long time ago, people didn't have those things, but the Chinese invented them!

slides.setup_instructions: Pre-cut potatoes in half. Have ink pads and paper ready. Display images of ancient Chinese woodblock printing.
slides.mascot_explanation: Alright, let's get our printing supplies ready! We've got potatoes or foam blocks to carve into, special tools for carving safely, ink pads or paint to make our stamps colorful, and paper to print on. We'll also look at some pictures of how people printed in China a super long time ago!

slides.text: 'Before paper was invented, people had to write on bamboo strips, animal skins, silk, or clay tablets. Imagine carrying a book made of bamboo — it could weigh 50 pounds! Then around 105 CE, a Chinese official named Cai Lun found a way to make thin, light sheets from tree bark and old rags. PAPER!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, imagine writing a whole story on heavy bamboo strips – that sounds like a lot of work! Before paper, that's what people used, along with other tricky materials. Then, a smart person named Cai Lun figured out how to make thin, light paper from plants and old cloth, which was a game-changer!

slides.text: 'Paper was amazing, but copying a book still meant writing every word by hand. Then Chinese inventors created woodblock printing — they carved an entire page of text into a wooden block, inked it, and pressed it onto paper. One block could make thousands of copies!'
slides.mascot_explanation: So, paper was awesome, but copying books was still slow because people had to write every single word by hand. Then the Chinese invented a super clever way called woodblock printing, where they carved a whole page onto wood, inked it up, and pressed it down to make lots of copies really fast!

slides.text: 'Later came movable type: individual stamps for each character that could be rearranged to print any page. These inventions changed the world — suddenly books became affordable and knowledge spread to millions of people. We will try printing ourselves!'
slides.mascot_explanation: After woodblock printing, they got even smarter and invented movable type, which were like little stamps for each letter that you could move around to make any words you wanted. These inventions made books way cheaper and helped everyone learn new things much faster, which is pretty incredible!

slides.prompt: Carve a simple design or letter (backwards!) into your potato or foam block. Ink it and press it onto paper. Make multiple copies — just like the ancient Chinese printers did! Try creating a repeating pattern or a simple message.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's your turn to be an inventor! Grab your potato or foam block and carefully carve a simple picture or letter – remember to carve it backwards! Then, carefully ink your stamp and press it onto the paper to make a print, just like they did in ancient China. Try making a pattern or a cool design!

slides.text: Paper and printing are two of China's Four Great Inventions. Without them, books, newspapers, and the spread of knowledge as we know it would not exist. Next time you write on paper or read a printed page, remember — that technology came from Ancient China!
slides.mastery_check: Can the student explain how papermaking and printing were invented in China and why these inventions were important?
slides.mascot_explanation: You did it! You just made prints like the ancient Chinese inventors did – how cool is that?! Remember, paper and printing are two of the most important inventions ever, and without them, we wouldn't have all the books and information we have today. You helped bring that history to life!

parent_notes: Paper and printing are arguably China's most impactful inventions. You can extend this lesson by trying actual papermaking — there are many simple tutorials online using a blender, screen, and recycled paper. The potato/foam printing activity gives children a hands-on feel for how woodblock printing works. Remind them that the image must be carved in REVERSE to print correctly — this is a great problem-solving challenge.

title: Read Aloud — The Silk Road Journey
description: A read-aloud session featuring a story or informational text about traveling the Silk Road. Students listen, visualize the journey, and connect to their history lesson.
instructions:
1. Choose a book about the Silk Road (suggestions: 'Traveling the Silk Road' or a similar children's text; or read a chapter from an encyclopedia/history book about the Silk Road).
2. Before reading: review the Silk Road map from today's history lesson.
3. As you read, pause to locate places mentioned on the map.
4. After reading: discuss the hardships of traveling the Silk Road (desert heat, mountain cold, bandits, sandstorms).
5. Students write a diary entry from the perspective of a Silk Road trader.
6. Share diary entries.
materials_needed: Book or text about the Silk Road

slides.heading: Read Aloud
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is like the cover of our adventure book! It tells us we're going to read a story about traveling a super long and famous path called the Silk Road. Get ready to imagine you're on a big journey!

slides.setup_instructions: Select an age-appropriate text about the Silk Road. Have the map from history class visible for reference.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, this slide shows us all the cool stuff we need for our Silk Road adventure. We have a book or story about the Silk Road, a map so we can see where everyone traveled, a special notebook called a journal, and some pencils for writing. Go grab all these things with a grown-up's help so we're ready to go!

slides.text: 'Today we are going to imagine ourselves as traders on the Silk Road. Before we read, look at our map. The journey from China to Rome was over 4,000 miles. What do you think that journey was like?'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, we're going to get our brains ready for our journey. Look at the map of the Silk Road – see how far it is from one end to the other? Imagine walking or riding a camel all that way for months and months! What do you think that super long trip would be like?

slides.text: Read the text aloud. Pause at key points: 'The traders entered the Taklamakan Desert — its name means Go in and you will not come out. Imagine the heat, the sand in your eyes, the thirst.' Point to locations on the map as they appear in the text.
slides.mascot_explanation: This is where the real adventure begins! As I read our story, listen closely to where the traders go. We'll find those places on our map, like the giant Taklamakan Desert – yikes, it sounds like a scary place! We'll imagine what it was like for the traders, feeling the hot sun and maybe getting sand in their eyes.

slides.text: After reading, discuss: 'What were the biggest dangers? Why did people risk this journey? What would you have traded?' Connect to the goods discussed in history: silk, spices, gold, glass.
slides.mascot_explanation: After we finish our story, we'll talk about how tricky and dangerous traveling the Silk Road was. We'll think about why people were brave enough to go on such hard trips, maybe carrying special things like shiny silk or yummy spices to trade. What do you think they would have wanted to trade?

slides.prompt: Write a diary entry as a Silk Road trader. Begin: 'Day 47 on the Silk Road...' Describe where you are, what you are carrying, what you have seen, and one challenge you faced today. Use details from the book and our lessons.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's your turn to be a Silk Road trader! In your journal, you'll pretend it's day 47 of your trip. Write about where you are, what amazing things you're carrying, something cool you saw, and one tough thing that happened today, just like a real trader would. You can use ideas from our book and our map!

slides.text: Your diary entries brought the Silk Road to life! Writing from a character's perspective helps us understand what life was really like in the past. The Silk Road traders were brave and adventurous people.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student describe details of Silk Road travel and write a creative journal entry from a trader's perspective?
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, you did such a great job writing like a Silk Road trader! Your diary entries really showed me what that journey might have felt like, with all the ups and downs. You were brave and creative, just like those traders from long ago who traveled so far!

parent_notes: Perspective writing (writing as a character from history) is a powerful tool for developing empathy and deep understanding. If you cannot find a specific Silk Road book, use encyclopedia entries or online articles read aloud. The diary entry exercise combines creative writing with historical knowledge — a hallmark of Montessori cross-curricular learning.

title: Creative Writing — Drafting a Short Story (Part 1)
description: Using their story maps from Day 3, students begin drafting their short stories. They focus on writing a strong beginning that introduces the character, setting, and hints at the problem.
instructions:
1. Review the student's story map from Day 3.
2. Discuss strong story openings: action, dialogue, or a vivid description of the setting.
3. Read examples of good opening paragraphs from published stories.
4. Model: write the opening paragraph of a sample story on the board.
5. Students draft their own opening paragraph (the beginning section of their story map).
6. Continue into the middle events if time allows.
7. Peer or parent review of the opening: Is the character introduced? Is the setting clear? Do we know there will be a problem?
materials_needed: Student's completed story map from Day 3

slides.heading: Creative Writing
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is showing us the title of what we're going to do today – we're going to start writing our very own short stories! It's like being the author of your own book.

slides.setup_instructions: Have the student's story map visible for reference. Mark several strong opening paragraphs in published books.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, let's get our supplies ready! We need your story map from last time – that's like our treasure map for the story. Your writing journal is where all the magic will happen on paper, and we need pencils and erasers for writing and fixing any oopsies. We also have some example openings to look at, which are like super-powered beginnings!

slides.text: 'Today we begin writing! A great story needs a great beginning. Here are three ways to start: with ACTION (Something exciting happening), with DIALOGUE (A character speaking), or with DESCRIPTION (Painting a picture of the setting with words).' Read an example of each.
slides.mascot_explanation: This is super important for making readers want to keep reading! We're learning three cool ways to start a story: you can jump right into the action with something exciting happening, start with a character talking, or paint a picture with words so the reader can imagine where and when the story is happening.

slides.text: Model by writing an opening paragraph on the board: 'The wind howled across the Great Wall as Li Wei pressed herself against the cold stone. She was supposed to be home by sunset, but the discovery she had made in the watchtower changed everything.' Discuss: what do we learn? (character, setting, hint of problem)
slides.mascot_explanation: Watch this! The teacher is going to write a beginning for a story right here. See how it tells us about Li Wei, where she is, and hints that something important happened? This helps us know who to follow and why we should care about what happens next.
