slides.text: 'Now look at YOUR story map. Who is your character? Where are they? What hint can you give about the problem? Write your opening paragraph — at least 4-5 sentences. Then continue with the events of your story.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's your turn to shine! Look back at your story map. Think about your main character, where they are, and what exciting or tricky thing might happen to them. Write down the very beginning of your story, like the teacher showed us, and then keep going with the next part!

slides.prompt: Using your story map as a guide, write the beginning of your short story. Include: introduce your main character, describe the setting, and hint at the problem. Then continue writing into the middle events. Aim for at least one full page.
slides.mascot_explanation: This is where you get to be the storyteller! Use your story map to write the first part of your adventure. Make sure you tell us who your character is, where they are, and give a little clue about what the big problem might be. Then, keep writing to tell us what happens next in the middle of your story.

slides.text: Read your opening paragraph aloud. Does it hook the reader? Does it introduce the character and setting? Great work! We will continue writing tomorrow, working on the middle and end of the story.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student write a story opening that introduces character, setting, and hints at the problem?
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, you wrote the beginning of your story! Let's read it aloud. Does it make someone want to know more? Did we meet your character and know where they are? You did such a fantastic job starting your story, and we'll build on this amazing start tomorrow!

parent_notes: The drafting stage is where the story map pays off. Encourage your child to follow their plan but also be open to new ideas that emerge during writing. Do not focus on spelling and grammar during drafting — the goal is to get ideas on paper. There will be time for editing later. If your child gets stuck, refer back to the story map for direction.

title: Decimals — Subtraction of Decimals
description: Students learn to subtract decimals by lining up the decimal points, following the same procedure as addition. They practice with and without regrouping (borrowing) and use hundred grids for verification.
instructions:
1. Review decimal addition from yesterday — same rules apply to subtraction.
2. Demonstrate: 0.8 - 0.3. Show on hundred grid: shade 80 squares, cross out 30. Remaining: 50 = 0.5.
3. Column subtraction: line up decimal points, subtract column by column.
4. With regrouping: 0.72 - 0.45. In hundredths: 2 - 5, need to borrow. 12 - 5 = 7 hundredths. 6 - 4 = 2 tenths. Answer: 0.27.
5. Tricky case: 0.5 - 0.23. Write 0.5 as 0.50 first, then subtract.
6. Practice set of 8 problems.
7. Word problems: 'You have $0.75 and spend $0.48. How much is left?'

slides.heading: Subtracting Decimals
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is like the title page for our new math adventure! It tells us we're going to learn how to subtract numbers that have decimal points, like 0.5 or 0.75, and the most important rule is to always line up those little dots, the decimal points, nice and straight.

slides.setup_instructions: Print hundred grids. Have the place value chart visible. Prepare practice problems of increasing difficulty.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, let's get our explorer gear ready for this math mission! We'll need those square grids that look like tiny checkerboards, some colorful pencils to mark things up, a whiteboard to practice on, a worksheet with problems, and a place value chart to help us keep our numbers organized. Make sure you have all these items with a grown-up's help!

slides.text: 'Subtracting decimals works just like adding them — line up the decimal points and subtract column by column.' Show 0.8 - 0.3 on a hundred grid: shade 80 squares, cross out 30. Count remaining: 50 = 0.5. Show the same problem in column form.
slides.mascot_explanation: Here's our first big math step! Subtracting decimals is super similar to adding them. The biggest trick is to line up the decimal points in a straight line, just like lining up your toy cars. Then, you subtract each column of numbers, starting from the right, and the slide shows us how to do it by coloring in and crossing out squares on our grid.

slides.text: 'What about 0.72 - 0.45? Look at the hundredths: 2 - 5. We cannot do that! So we borrow from the tenths, just like with whole numbers. Now it is 12 - 5 = 7 hundredths, and 6 - 4 = 2 tenths. Answer: 0.27.' Verify on the hundred grid.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we're going to try a problem where we need to do a little borrowing, just like when you borrow a crayon from a friend! If we look at the tiny numbers in the hundredths place and the top one is smaller, we need to "borrow" from the number next door. The slide shows us how to do that so we can figure out the answer.

slides.text: 'Here is a tricky one: 0.5 - 0.23. The numbers have different lengths! The trick: rewrite 0.5 as 0.50. Now we can subtract: 0.50 - 0.23 = 0.27.' Adding a zero after the last decimal digit does not change the value. Practice: 0.6 - 0.14, 0.9 - 0.37.
slides.mascot_explanation: This next problem looks a little tricky because the numbers don't have the same number of digits after the decimal point, but we have a secret weapon! We can just add a zero to the end of the shorter number – it doesn't change its value, but it makes it easy to subtract. Think of it like adding an extra space to make everything fit perfectly.

slides.prompt: Solve: (1) 0.9 - 0.4, (2) 0.67 - 0.31, (3) 0.83 - 0.56, (4) 0.70 - 0.25, (5) 0.5 - 0.18, (6) 1.0 - 0.64. Word problem: You have $0.75 and buy a sticker for $0.48. How much change do you receive?
slides.mascot_explanation: Alright, it's your turn to be the math whiz! You'll solve a bunch of subtraction problems, some with decimals and one that's like a real-life money question about getting change back. Just remember to line up those decimal points and borrow if you need to, you've totally got this!

slides.text: Subtracting decimals uses the same rules as adding them: line up the decimal points, add zeros if needed to make the numbers the same length, then subtract column by column with regrouping when necessary. You now know how to add AND subtract decimals!
slides.mastery_check: Can the student subtract decimals to the hundredths place, including problems requiring regrouping and filling in trailing zeros?
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, you did it! We learned that subtracting decimals is just like adding them – line up the points, add zeros if needed, and subtract column by column, borrowing when necessary. You're now a pro at adding *and* subtracting decimals, which is super impressive!

parent_notes: The biggest challenges with decimal subtraction are: (1) remembering to line up the decimal point, (2) handling numbers with different numbers of decimal places, and (3) regrouping across the decimal point. Money problems are excellent practice since children are motivated to figure out how much change they get. Practice with real coins at the store.

title: Insect Life Cycles — Complete Metamorphosis
description: Students learn about complete metamorphosis: the four-stage life cycle of insects like butterflies, beetles, and flies (egg, larva, pupa, adult). They compare this to incomplete metamorphosis.
instructions:
1. Review insect body parts from Day 2.
2. Ask: 'Does a caterpillar look like a butterfly? They are the same animal! How is that possible?'
3. Introduce metamorphosis: a dramatic change in form during an insect's life.
4. Complete metamorphosis has 4 stages: egg, larva (caterpillar), pupa (chrysalis/cocoon), adult.
5. Show images of each stage for a butterfly and a beetle.
6. Briefly mention incomplete metamorphosis: egg, nymph, adult (grasshopper). Only 3 stages.
7. Students create a circular life cycle diagram for a butterfly showing all 4 stages with illustrations.
8. Compare: butterfly vs. grasshopper life cycles.
materials_needed: Drawing paper (circular format or paper plates)
Optional: live caterpillars or butterfly kit

slides.heading: Insect Life Cycles
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is like the title page for our exciting adventure into how some insects grow and change! It tells us we're going to learn about "Complete Metamorphosis," which is a super fancy word for a really amazing transformation that insects go through. Isn't it neat that we get to explore this cool science topic?

slides.setup_instructions: Print clear images of butterfly and beetle life cycle stages. Prepare paper plates divided into 4 sections for the life cycle diagram.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, this slide shows us all the cool stuff we'll need for our project! We've got pictures showing the different steps of an insect's life, a paper plate that we'll use to draw a circle, and colorful pencils or markers to make our drawings pop. There's also a chart that will help us remember everything, like a helpful cheat sheet!

slides.text: 'Look at this caterpillar. Now look at this butterfly. Would you believe they are the SAME animal? This amazing transformation is called METAMORPHOSIS — it comes from Greek words meaning change of form.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at this! See the wiggly caterpillar and then the beautiful butterfly? This slide is asking us to think about how they can be the same animal, even though they look so different. This big change is called metamorphosis, and it's like a magical costume change that some insects do as they grow up.

slides.text: 'Complete metamorphosis has FOUR stages: (1) EGG — the mother lays tiny eggs on a plant. (2) LARVA — a caterpillar hatches and eats constantly, growing bigger and bigger. (3) PUPA — the caterpillar forms a chrysalis and its body completely transforms inside. (4) ADULT — a butterfly emerges with wings!'
slides.mascot_explanation: This is where we learn about the four special steps of complete metamorphosis! First, there's the tiny EGG. Then, out hatches the LARVA, which is a hungry caterpillar that just eats and eats. After that comes the PUPA stage, where the caterpillar makes a cozy chrysalis to hide in while it changes. Finally, the ADULT butterfly or beetle emerges, ready to fly!

slides.text: 'Not all insects go through 4 stages. Some, like grasshoppers, have INCOMPLETE metamorphosis — only 3 stages: egg, nymph (a small version of the adult), and adult. The nymph looks like a tiny adult and just grows bigger, shedding its skin as it grows. No pupa stage!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, this slide shows us that not all insects change this much. Some, like grasshoppers, have a simpler change called incomplete metamorphosis, which only has three steps: egg, nymph (which looks like a mini-grasshopper!), and then the adult. They don't have that quiet pupa stage where all the big changes happen inside.

slides.prompt: Create a circular life cycle diagram on a paper plate. Divide it into 4 sections and illustrate: egg, larva (caterpillar), pupa (chrysalis), and adult (butterfly). Label each stage and draw arrows showing the direction. On the back, write 2-3 sentences about each stage.
slides.mascot_explanation: Alright, it's time to make our own life cycle circle! Grab your paper plate and your coloring tools. We need to draw four sections for the four stages: egg, larva (that's the caterpillar!), pupa (the chrysalis!), and the adult butterfly. Make sure to draw arrows to show how the stages connect in a circle, and write the name of each stage in its spot. You've got this!

slides.text: Complete metamorphosis is one of nature's most amazing processes. The caterpillar literally dissolves inside the chrysalis and rebuilds itself as a butterfly! Butterflies, beetles, flies, and ants all go through complete metamorphosis. Grasshoppers and dragonflies use incomplete metamorphosis.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student describe the four stages of complete metamorphosis and explain the difference from incomplete metamorphosis?
slides.mascot_explanation: We did it! We learned that some insects like butterflies go through four amazing stages, changing completely from a caterpillar to a butterfly, and it's called complete metamorphosis. Other insects, like grasshoppers, have a simpler change with only three stages. Isn't it incredible how nature works its magic?

parent_notes: Metamorphosis is one of the most captivating science topics for children. Consider ordering a butterfly kit to observe the process in real time — watching a caterpillar form a chrysalis and emerge as a butterfly is unforgettable. Many educational supply companies sell them. The process takes about 3 weeks. If that is not possible, excellent time-lapse videos are available online.

title: Geometry — Exploring Symmetry
description: Students explore line symmetry through hands-on activities. They identify lines of symmetry in shapes, letters, and real objects, and create symmetrical designs using folding and painting techniques.
instructions:
1. Fold a piece of paper in half and cut out a shape. Unfold: both sides match! This is symmetry.
2. Define line of symmetry: a line that divides a shape into two mirror-image halves.
3. Test shapes: does a square have a line of symmetry? (Yes — 4!) Rectangle? (Yes — 2.) Triangle? (Depends on the type.)
4. Test letters: A, B, C, D... which have vertical symmetry? Horizontal? Both?
5. Look for symmetry in nature: butterflies, leaves, faces, flowers.
6. Activity: fold paper, drop paint on one side, fold and press — open to reveal a symmetrical design.
7. Draw 5 shapes and mark all lines of symmetry.

slides.heading: Geometry
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide is all about geometry, which is the study of shapes and their properties, and specifically, we're going to learn about something super cool called "lines of symmetry." It's like a secret code that shapes have that makes them look the same on both sides!

slides.setup_instructions: Pre-cut some geometric shapes from paper. Have mirrors and paint ready. Cover the workspace for the paint activity.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, let's get our supplies ready for some fun! We've got paper for folding and cutting, scissors to make our shapes, and some colorful paint or ink for a special surprise. We also have pre-cut geometric shapes to look at, some little mirrors to help us see symmetry, and rulers and pencils for drawing lines. Make sure you have all these things with you!

slides.text: 'Watch this: I fold this paper in half and cut a shape along the fold. When I open it... both sides are exactly the same! This is called SYMMETRY. The fold line is called the LINE OF SYMMETRY — it divides the shape into two matching halves.'
slides.mascot_explanation: This first step shows us how to make symmetry! See how the paper is folded in half, and then a shape is cut along the fold? When you open it up, POOF! Both sides are exactly the same, like a mirror image. That special fold line that makes them match is called the "line of symmetry."

slides.text: 'How can we test for symmetry? Place a mirror along a line. If the reflection and the real shape together look like the original shape, that is a line of symmetry!' Test a square: 'It has FOUR lines of symmetry — horizontal, vertical, and two diagonal.' Test a rectangle: 'Only TWO — horizontal and vertical. The diagonals do not work!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we're going to be detectives and look for lines of symmetry! We can use these mirrors to help us. If you put a mirror on a line and the reflection makes the shape look exactly the same, then that line is a line of symmetry! A square has four of them, but a rectangle only has two – let's see if you can find them!

slides.text: 'Symmetry is everywhere in nature! Butterflies have perfect symmetry. Your face is almost symmetrical. Flowers often have multiple lines of symmetry. Even Chinese art uses symmetry in its designs.' Show examples.
slides.mascot_explanation: Isn't it neat how symmetry shows up everywhere? This slide is showing us that nature is full of it – like beautiful butterflies, or even the petals on a flower, and your own face is pretty symmetrical too! We'll look for these matching halves all around us.

slides.prompt: Part 1: Fold paper in half, drip paint on one side, fold and press, then open to see your symmetrical design. Part 2: Draw these shapes and mark ALL lines of symmetry: square, rectangle, equilateral triangle, circle, regular hexagon. How many does each have?
slides.mascot_explanation: Get ready for the best part – our art activity! First, fold your paper in half, then carefully drip some paint on just one side, fold it again, and gently press. When you open it up, you'll have a surprise symmetrical design! After that, you'll draw some shapes and draw all the lines of symmetry you can find on them.

slides.text: A line of symmetry divides a shape into two mirror-image halves. Some shapes have many lines of symmetry (a circle has infinite!), while some shapes have none. Look for symmetry in nature, art, and architecture this week!
slides.mastery_check: Can the student identify and draw lines of symmetry for basic geometric shapes?
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, you did it! We learned that a line of symmetry is like a magic line that cuts a shape into two perfectly matching pieces. You discovered that some shapes have lots of these lines, and some have none, and you even created your own symmetrical art! Keep an eye out for symmetry in the world around you – it's everywhere!

parent_notes: Symmetry is a geometry concept that connects beautifully to art and nature. The paint-fold activity produces stunning results and is very memorable. After this lesson, go on a symmetry hunt around your home and neighborhood — architecture, nature, and design all use symmetry. The mirror test is an excellent hands-on way to verify lines of symmetry.

title: Chinese Music — Pentatonic Scale and Instruments
description: Students learn about traditional Chinese music, the pentatonic scale, and Chinese instruments. They listen to examples and experiment with creating pentatonic melodies.
instructions:
1. Introduce Chinese music: one of the oldest musical traditions in the world.
2. The pentatonic scale uses 5 notes (penta = five). On a piano: C, D, E, G, A (no F or B).
3. Play or listen to a pentatonic melody — it sounds distinctly Asian/Chinese.
4. Introduce instruments: erhu (2-string fiddle), pipa (lute), guzheng (zither), dizi (bamboo flute).
5. Listen to recordings of each instrument.
6. Students experiment with pentatonic melodies on available instruments (xylophone, piano, or tone bars — remove F and B bars).
7. Create a simple composition using only pentatonic notes.
materials_needed: Images of Chinese instruments (erhu, pipa, guzheng, dizi)
Optional: remove F and B bars from xylophone

slides.heading: Chinese Music
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is like the cover of our special music book! It's introducing us to the exciting world of Chinese music and a special musical pattern called the pentatonic scale. We're going to learn all about it!

slides.setup_instructions: Queue up audio/video recordings of erhu, pipa, guzheng, and dizi performances. If using a xylophone, remove the F and B bars to create a pentatonic instrument.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, look at this list! We'll need a xylophone or keyboard to make music, some recordings to listen to, pictures of cool instruments, and paper to write our own songs. If you're using a xylophone, we'll take out two bars so it only has the special "pentatonic" notes.

slides.text: 'Chinese music is one of the oldest in the world — over 3,000 years old! It sounds different from Western music because it uses a special scale with only FIVE notes instead of seven. This is called the PENTATONIC scale. Penta means five, like pentagon.'
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide is telling us how super old Chinese music is – it’s been around for thousands of years! It sounds so unique because it uses a scale with only five notes, called the pentatonic scale. "Penta" means five, like how a pentagon has five sides!

slides.text: 'Let us hear some traditional Chinese instruments.' Play recordings: 'The ERHU is like a violin with only two strings — listen to its singing, emotional sound. The PIPA is like a guitar played upright. The GUZHENG has 21 strings stretched across a long board. The DIZI is a bamboo flute.' Show images of each.
slides.mascot_explanation: Get ready to meet some amazing Chinese instruments! We'll hear the erhu, which is like a violin but with just two strings, and the pipa, which is kind of like a guitar. We'll also see the guzheng, a big instrument with lots of strings, and the dizi, a beautiful bamboo flute.

slides.text: 'Now let us make our own pentatonic music! On the xylophone, we only use these notes: C, D, E, G, A. Play any combination of these notes and it will sound beautiful — you almost cannot make a mistake with the pentatonic scale!' Demonstrate a simple melody.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's time for the fun part – making music! We're going to play only these five notes: C, D, E, G, and A. When you play these notes together, it sounds like magic, and it's almost impossible to play a "wrong" note!

slides.prompt: Experiment with the pentatonic scale (C, D, E, G, A) on the xylophone or keyboard. Create a short melody — at least 8 notes long. Practice it until you can play it smoothly. Write down your melody using letter names so you can remember it.
slides.mascot_explanation: This is your chance to be a composer! Grab your instrument and play a little tune using only the C, D, E, G, and A notes. Try to make it at least eight notes long and play it smoothly. When you like it, write down the note letters on your paper so you don't forget your awesome song!

slides.text: The pentatonic scale is the foundation of Chinese music, but it is also found in music from Japan, Africa, Scotland, and even American blues! When you hear music that sounds Asian, it is often because it uses these same five notes.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student identify the pentatonic scale and create a simple melody using only pentatonic notes?
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, you made your own pentatonic melody! That special five-note scale isn't just in Chinese music; it's all over the world, even in some blues music you might know. You learned how to use it to create your own beautiful song!

parent_notes: The pentatonic scale is magical because almost any combination of its five notes sounds pleasing. This makes it perfect for children's first composition experience. YouTube has excellent performances of all four instruments mentioned. The connection between Chinese music and the pentatonic scale is a great example of how culture influences art. Even many Western songs use the pentatonic scale (Amazing Grace, for example).

title: Creative Writing — Completing and Revising the Short Story
description: Students finish drafting their short stories, then learn basic revision strategies: adding detail, checking sentence variety, and reading aloud to catch errors.
instructions:
1. Students continue writing from where they left off on Day 4.
2. Focus on the ending: the problem must be solved, the character must have changed or learned something.
3. Once the draft is complete, introduce revision:
   - Read aloud: does it sound natural? Are there awkward sentences?
   - Check for sentence variety: do all sentences start the same way? Mix short and long sentences.
   - Add detail: find two places to add descriptive words or dialogue.
4. Students revise their stories based on these three checks.
5. Write a final copy or prepare to share.
6. Author's chair: students read their stories aloud to the class/family.

slides.heading: Creative Writing
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is like the cover of our amazing writing adventure! It's telling us that we're going to be creative writers, and our big goal today is to finish the stories we've started and then make them even more awesome by revising them. It's like building with LEGOs – first you get all the pieces together, and then you make your creation super cool!

slides.setup_instructions: Have the student's draft ready. Prepare a simple revision checklist: (1) Read aloud, (2) Sentence variety, (3) Add details.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, now we need to gather our tools for writing and revising. We'll need the story draft you were working on before, which is like the first version of your amazing idea. Your writing journal is where you can jot down new thoughts, and pencils with erasers are super important for making changes. The revision checklist is like a secret map to making your story shine!

slides.text: 'Today we finish our stories and make them even better! First, complete your story. Remember: the ending must solve the problem. Your character should have changed or learned something. A good ending leaves the reader satisfied.'
slides.mascot_explanation: This step is all about finishing the adventure in your story! Think about your main character – did they solve the problem they were facing? And importantly, did they learn something new or change a little bit by the end? Making sure your story has a good ending is like giving your reader a happy hug after a fun journey.

slides.text: 'Now let us revise. First: READ ALOUD. When you hear your story out loud, you catch things your eyes miss. Second: CHECK SENTENCE VARIETY — not every sentence should start with The or I. Mix it up! Third: ADD DETAIL — find two places where you can add a descriptive word or a line of dialogue.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's time to be a story detective and make your writing even stronger! First, you're going to read your story out loud, because your ears can hear tricky sentences that your eyes might miss. Then, you'll check to see if you used lots of different sentence beginnings, not just "I" or "The" over and over. Finally, you'll add more exciting details or even a fun conversation to make your story pop!

slides.text: 'Use a colored pencil to make revision marks on your draft. Add a caret (^) where you want to insert words. Cross out words you want to remove. Draw an arrow if you want to move a sentence. Revision is what turns good writing into GREAT writing!'
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide shows us how authors make changes to their stories. You'll use a colored pencil to mark up your draft, kind of like drawing on a map to show where to go next. A little caret symbol (^) means "add something here," crossing out means "take this away," and an arrow means "move this part." These marks help you polish your story until it's perfect!

slides.prompt: Complete your story draft if not yet finished. Then revise using the three-step checklist: (1) read aloud and fix awkward parts, (2) vary your sentence beginnings, (3) add descriptive details in at least two places. When ready, write your final copy neatly or prepare to read aloud.
slides.mascot_explanation: Alright, this is where you get to put everything we've learned into action! You'll finish writing the last part of your story, making sure the ending is just right. Then, use those revision tricks we just talked about: read it aloud, mix up your sentences, and add some extra descriptive words or dialogue. Once it's super polished, you'll write a clean final copy or get ready to share your masterpiece!

slides.text: Author's chair! Read your story aloud to your audience. You planned, drafted, and revised an original short story this week. That is what real authors do! Your story has characters, a setting, a problem, and a solution — all the ingredients of great fiction.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student complete a short story with a clear beginning, middle, and end, and demonstrate basic revision skills?
slides.mascot_explanation: Woohoo, you did it! This is the author's chair, where you get to share your amazing, finished story with everyone! Think about it – you took an idea, wrote a whole story with characters and a problem and a solution, and then you made it even better. You're officially a published author, just like the ones in books!

parent_notes: Completing a full short story — from planning to drafting to revision — is a major accomplishment. Celebrate your child's work! The revision process is particularly important: professional writers revise many times. Help your child see that revision is not about fixing mistakes but about making good writing even better. Save these stories in a writing portfolio.

title: Decimals — Word Problems and Review
description: Students apply their decimal skills to real-world word problems involving money, measurement, and everyday situations. This lesson reviews all decimal concepts from the week: hundredths, comparing, adding, and subtracting.
instructions:
1. Quick review: reading decimals, comparing, adding, subtracting.
2. Present word problems involving money:
   - 'A book costs $4.75 and a bookmark costs $1.25. What is the total?'
   - 'You have $5.00 and buy a snack for $2.38. How much change?'
3. Present measurement problems:
   - 'A caterpillar is 3.5 cm long. It grows 1.8 cm. How long is it now?'
4. Students solve a set of 8-10 word problems independently.
5. Challenge: multi-step problems combining addition and subtraction.
6. Students create their own word problem for a partner to solve.

slides.heading: Decimal Word Problems
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is like the title page of a cool adventure book! It tells us that today we're going to become super problem-solvers using everything we've learned about decimals, especially when we see them in real life. It's like putting all the puzzle pieces together!

slides.setup_instructions: Prepare 8-10 word problems of increasing difficulty. Have play money available for students who need a concrete model.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, this slide shows us all the tools we'll need for our math adventure today, like a treasure map! We've got a worksheet with problems, a whiteboard to write on, maybe some play money to help us count, special grids for lining things up, and of course, our trusty pencils. If you don't have these, just ask a grown-up to help you find them!

slides.text: Quick review: 'This week we learned about hundredths, comparing decimals, adding decimals, and subtracting decimals. Today we use ALL of those skills to solve real-world problems. The key to word problems: read carefully, decide the operation, line up the decimal points, and solve.'
slides.mascot_explanation: This is like the wise owl giving us some important tips before we start! We're going to quickly remember how to read decimals, compare them to see which is bigger, and how to add and subtract them. The super important part is to read each word problem very carefully, figure out if we need to add or subtract, and always line up those decimal points like little soldiers before we solve.

slides.text: Model a problem: 'A book costs $4.75 and a bookmark costs $1.25. What is the total?' Identify: we need to ADD. Set up: 4.75 + 1.25. Line up decimal points. Solve: $6.00. Check: does this make sense? Yes, about $5 + $1 = $6.
slides.mascot_explanation: Here, we're going to look at an example of how to solve a money problem where we need to find the total cost. Imagine buying a book and a bookmark – to find out how much both cost together, we need to add the prices, making sure those decimal points are perfectly lined up. We’ll check our answer to make sure it makes sense, just like a detective checking clues!

slides.text: Model a subtraction problem: 'You have $5.00 and buy a snack for $2.38. How much change?' Set up: 5.00 - 2.38. Solve: $2.62. Estimation check: $5 - $2 = about $3. Our answer $2.62 is close, so it makes sense.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, we'll see how to figure out how much money we get back after buying something, which is called change. If you have $5.00 and buy a yummy snack for $2.38, we need to subtract the snack's cost from the money you have. We’ll line up the decimals again and then check our answer using a quick guess, like thinking $5 minus $2 is about $3.

slides.prompt: Solve 8 word problems involving decimals (money and measurement). Show your work and check each answer with estimation. Then create your own decimal word problem and write it on a separate paper — include the answer key on the back!
slides.mascot_explanation: This is where you get to be the math detective! You'll solve 8 problems that are like little stories using money and measurements, showing all your work and checking your answers with a quick estimate. Then, the really fun part: you get to create your OWN word problem for a friend to solve and write the answer on the back!

slides.text: You have mastered decimals to the hundredths place this week! You can read them, compare them, add them, and subtract them. Decimals are everywhere: money, measurements, sports scores, and science. Keep practicing with real-life situations!
slides.mastery_check: Can the student solve multi-step word problems involving decimal addition and subtraction in real-world contexts?
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at everything you've accomplished this week! You’ve become a decimal whiz, understanding how to read, compare, add, and subtract them. Decimals are super useful for things like money, measuring how tall things are, and even in science experiments, so keep looking for them everywhere you go!

parent_notes: Word problems are the ultimate test of mathematical understanding because they require students to choose the correct operation, not just compute. Practice at home: have your child calculate the total at the grocery store, figure out change, or measure objects and add/subtract the measurements. Creating their own word problems is an especially powerful learning activity.

title: China — Population, Cities, and Modern Life
description: Students explore modern China: its enormous population, major cities (Beijing, Shanghai, Hong Kong), and how ancient traditions blend with modern life. They compare population density to other countries.
instructions:
1. China's population: about 1.4 billion people — the most of any country until recently passed by India.
2. Compare: 'If our class had 100 students, 18 of them would be Chinese.' Use proportional representation.
3. Show major cities on the map: Beijing (capital, Forbidden City), Shanghai (largest, modern skyline), Hong Kong (harbor city).
4. Discuss: most people live in the eastern part of China near rivers. Western China is mostly empty (mountains, desert).
5. Modern vs. ancient: high-speed trains alongside ancient temples, smartphones alongside calligraphy.
6. Students create an infographic about China: population, area, capital, major cities, fun facts.
7. Compare China's population to their own country.
materials_needed: Photos of modern and ancient China

slides.heading: Modern China
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is like the title page for our adventure into China! It tells us we're going to learn all about modern China, like how many people live there, what its big cities are like, and how people live their lives today, mixing old and new things. It's like getting ready to explore a brand new place!

items: Photos of modern and ancient China
slides.setup_instructions: Prepare population comparison data. Print photos showing the contrast of ancient and modern China side by side.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, this slide shows us all the cool stuff we'll need for our China exploration! We have a map to find our way around, charts to see how many people live there, and pictures that show how China is both super old and super new at the same time. We'll also need paper, colored pencils, markers, and a ruler to make something awesome later on. Go grab these with a grown-up and bring them back!

slides.text: 'China has about 1.4 BILLION people. That is 1,400,000,000! If you counted one person per second, it would take you about 44 YEARS to count everyone in China. About 1 out of every 6 people on Earth lives in China!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Wowza, look at that number! This slide is telling us China has about 1.4 BILLION people – that's a LOT of people, more than you can even imagine! To help us understand, imagine if our whole class was 100 students, 18 of them would be from China. It means China has the most people in the whole world, or very close to it.

slides.text: 'Where do all these people live? Look at the map — almost everyone lives in the EASTERN half, near the rivers and coast. The west has the Himalayas, the Tibetan Plateau, and the Gobi Desert — very hard to live in! The biggest cities are Beijing (the capital), Shanghai (the largest), and Hong Kong.'
slides.mascot_explanation: This map is showing us where all those billions of people live in China. See how most of the dots are on the eastern side, near the big rivers and the ocean? That's because it's easier to live and grow food there, unlike the western part which has huge mountains and deserts. We also see the names of three super important cities: Beijing, Shanghai, and Hong Kong.

slides.text: Show contrasting photos: 'Modern China has the fastest trains in the world, incredible skyscrapers, and cutting-edge technology. But it also preserves ancient traditions: calligraphy, tea ceremonies, martial arts, and festivals like Chinese New Year. Ancient and modern exist side by side.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Get ready for some amazing sights! This slide shows how China is like a time traveler, with super-fast modern trains and tall, shiny buildings right next to ancient temples and people practicing old traditions like calligraphy. It's like seeing a knight in shining armor using a smartphone – both old and new things exist together!

slides.prompt: Create a China infographic on a large sheet of paper. Include: the country name in both English and Chinese characters, population, area, capital city, 3 major cities, 2 rivers, and 5 fun facts from this week's lessons. Add illustrations and make it colorful!
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's your turn to be the expert! You get to make a colorful poster, called an infographic, all about China using what we've learned. You'll write its name, how many people live there, where the capital and big cities are, name some rivers, and add some cool facts. Don't forget to draw pictures to make it look super exciting!

slides.text: This week we explored Ancient China and modern China. We learned about the Great Wall, the Silk Road, Chinese inventions, rivers and mountains, and the enormous population. China's civilization is over 4,000 years old and still thriving today!
slides.mastery_check: Can the student describe China's population distribution, locate major cities, and explain how ancient traditions coexist with modern life?
slides.mascot_explanation: You did it! We've just finished our amazing journey learning about China, from its super-big population and busy cities to how it keeps its ancient traditions alive right alongside the newest technology. You learned so much, and now you can tell others about China's fascinating mix of old and new!

parent_notes: This lesson brings the Ancient China unit into the present day. Children are often amazed by the scale of China's population. The infographic activity synthesizes the entire week's learning. If possible, visit a Chinese restaurant this week and talk about how Chinese food in America differs from traditional Chinese cuisine. You might also explore Chinese New Year traditions if the timing is right.

title: Chinese Inventions — Compass and Gunpowder
description: Students learn about the remaining two of China's Four Great Inventions: the magnetic compass and gunpowder. They explore how these inventions spread along the Silk Road and changed the world.
instructions:
1. Review: 'We learned about paper and printing. Today: two more inventions that changed everything.'
2. The compass: Chinese discovered that a lodestone points north. Used for navigation.
3. Demonstrate with a simple compass: how it always points north. Discuss why this matters for travelers.
4. Gunpowder: originally created by Chinese alchemists looking for an elixir of life! First used for fireworks.
5. Later used for weapons, which changed warfare forever.
6. Both inventions traveled along the Silk Road to the rest of the world.
7. Students create a 'Four Great Inventions' poster showing all four inventions with dates and descriptions.
materials_needed: Magnet and needle (for DIY compass demonstration)
Images of all Four Great Inventions
Bowl of water and cork (for floating needle compass)

slides.heading: Chinese Inventions
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is like the title page of our adventure! It tells us we're going to learn about some super important things that people in China invented a long, long time ago. We'll be focusing on two very cool ones: the compass and gunpowder.

slides.setup_instructions: Have a real compass ready to demonstrate. Prepare materials for a simple DIY compass: magnetize a needle by stroking it with a magnet, place on a cork floating in water.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, this slide shows us all the cool stuff we need for our activities today! We have a real compass to see how it works, a magnet and a needle that we'll turn into our *own* compass, and big poster paper for our project. We also have a bowl of water, a little cork to help our needle float, and colorful markers to make our poster amazing!

slides.text: 'The Chinese discovered something amazing about a special rock called LODESTONE — it always points the same direction! They realized it points NORTH. Imagine how useful that is: even in fog, in the dark, or on the open ocean, you always know which way is north. They invented the COMPASS!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, this is where we learn about the compass! The slide says that people in China found a special rock that always pointed north. Think about being lost in the woods or on a big, blue ocean – knowing which way is north would be a lifesaver, right? That's exactly why they invented the compass, so travelers would never get lost again!

slides.text: Demonstrate with a real compass and a DIY floating needle compass. 'See? No matter which way we turn it, the needle swings back to north. Before the compass, sailors had to navigate by the stars — if it was cloudy, they were lost! The compass changed everything about exploration and trade.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we get to see the compass in action! The slide explains that we'll use both a real compass and the one we make ourselves to see how the needle *always* points north. This was way better than trying to figure things out by looking at the stars, especially when it was cloudy! It made traveling and trading much, much easier.

slides.text: 'The last Great Invention is GUNPOWDER. Chinese alchemists were actually trying to create a potion for eternal life! Instead, they accidentally made a mixture that EXPLODES. At first, they used it for fireworks — those were invented in China too! Later it was used in weapons, completely changing warfare.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Get ready for fireworks and more! This slide tells us about gunpowder, which was actually invented by accident by people trying to find a magic potion to live forever. Can you believe it? First, they used it to make loud and colorful fireworks, but later, it changed how people fought wars forever.

slides.prompt: Create a 'Four Great Inventions of China' poster. For each invention (paper, printing, compass, gunpowder), include: a drawing, the approximate date of invention, a short description, and how it changed the world. Make it colorful and informative!
slides.mascot_explanation: This is our big project time! We get to make a super cool poster showing all four of China's Great Inventions: paper, printing, the compass, and gunpowder. You'll draw a picture for each one, write down when it was invented, and explain how it made the world a different place. Make it colorful and fun!

slides.text: Paper, printing, the compass, and gunpowder — four inventions from Ancient China that changed the course of human history. All four spread across the world via the Silk Road. Next week, we travel west to Ancient Greece!
slides.mastery_check: Can the student name all Four Great Inventions of China and explain the significance of each?
slides.mascot_explanation: We did it! We've learned about four amazing inventions from China that traveled all over the world and changed everything. We saw how paper and printing helped share ideas, how the compass helped people explore, and how gunpowder changed things too. Great job learning about these incredible inventions!

parent_notes: The Four Great Inventions of China are a cornerstone of world history education. The compass experiment (magnetizing a needle and floating it on water) is a wonderful hands-on science activity. Gunpowder's origin as a failed medicine is a great example of accidental discovery in science. These inventions all traveled the Silk Road — reinforce that connection from earlier this week.

title: Read Aloud — Chinese Folktale
description: A read-aloud of a traditional Chinese folktale, connecting to the Ancient China unit. Students explore themes, morals, and cultural values reflected in the story.
instructions:
1. Choose a Chinese folktale (suggestions: 'The Empty Pot' by Demi, 'Lon Po Po' by Ed Young, or 'The Seven Chinese Brothers').
2. Before reading: 'What is a folktale? A story passed down through generations that teaches a lesson.'
3. Read the story aloud with expression and pauses for prediction.
4. After reading: discuss the theme/moral. What lesson does the story teach?
5. Compare to folktales from other cultures — do any have similar themes?
6. Students write the moral of the story and draw their favorite scene.
7. Share responses.

slides.heading: Read Aloud
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is like the cover of a special book we're going to read today! It tells us we're going to dive into a wonderful story from China, called a folktale. Get ready for an adventure!

slides.setup_instructions: Select a Chinese folktale appropriate for ages 6-9. Preview and mark discussion points. 'The Empty Pot' by Demi is excellent and widely available.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, let's get our tools ready for this storytelling adventure! We need the folktale book itself, a special notebook called a reading journal, some colored pencils to make our drawings pop, and regular pencils for writing. Make sure you have all these things nearby so we can jump right into the story!

slides.text: 'All week we have been learning about Ancient China. Today we will read a folktale — a story that Chinese families have told their children for hundreds of years. Folktales carry the values and wisdom of a culture.' Introduce the book and show the cover.
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide is like the beginning of our storytelling journey. It tells us that folktales are super old stories that families have shared for a long, long time, and they often teach us important lessons about how to be good people, just like we've been learning about Ancient China.

slides.text: Read the story aloud with expression. Pause at key moments: 'What do you think will happen next? Why do you think the character did that? What would YOU do in this situation?' Encourage predictions and connections.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's time for the best part – listening to the story! As I read, I'll stop sometimes to ask you what you think might happen next, or why a character did something. Your job is to listen carefully and share your amazing ideas and predictions!

slides.text: After reading: 'What lesson does this story teach? This lesson is called the MORAL or THEME of the story.' Discuss Chinese cultural values that appear: honesty, respect for elders, hard work, wisdom. 'Do you know any stories from other cultures that teach a similar lesson?'
slides.mascot_explanation: After our story, we'll talk about the big lesson the story taught us, which is called the "moral" or "theme." We'll think about how this lesson might show what people in Ancient China thought was important, like being honest or working hard, and if you know any other stories that teach us something similar.

slides.prompt: In your reading journal: (1) Write the title and a one-sentence summary of the story. (2) Write the moral/lesson of the story. (3) Draw your favorite scene with as much detail as possible. (4) Write one sentence about how this story connects to what you learned about China this week.
slides.mascot_explanation: This is where you get to be the artist and writer! In your journal, you'll write down the story's name and what it was about in one sentence, then write down the big lesson it taught. After that, draw your very favorite part of the story with lots of color and detail!

slides.text: Folktales help us understand what a culture values most. Chinese folktales often teach about honesty, patience, cleverness, and respect. This week we traveled through Ancient China — its Great Wall, Silk Road, inventions, geography, art, and stories. What an amazing civilization!
slides.mastery_check: Can the student identify the moral of a folktale and connect it to the cultural context of Ancient China?
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, we finished our folktale and activity! See how stories can teach us so much, not just about being good people, but also about different places like Ancient China? You did a fantastic job writing the lesson and drawing your favorite part – that's how we learn about cultures!

parent_notes: Chinese folktales are rich with wisdom and often feature themes of honesty, humility, and respect for nature. 'The Empty Pot' by Demi is perhaps the best-known Chinese picture book in English — its message about honesty is universal. After reading, explore more Chinese folktales at the library. Each one opens a window into Chinese values and traditions. This closes our Ancient China unit beautifully.
